sen.e: She was also a prominent pro emperor activist and a scholar of the study of Chinese and later became an education grand master (tutor) to Haruko ICHIJO (later to become Empress Dowager Shoken).

sen.j: 実家の若江家は菅原氏の系譜に連なる公家ではあったが、戦国時代 (日本)の混乱のため絶家、江戸時代になって徳川家光からの申し入れにより再興されたが、後水尾天皇の勅勘をくらい、それがきっかけとなり堂上家から地下家に転落した家柄であった。
sen.e: While her family was the court nobility, the chaos of the Sengoku Period vanquished the lineage without a successor, but was reinstated by request of Iemitsu TOKUGAWA despite the lineage being demoted from Tosho-ke to Jige-ke as a result of disownment by Emperor Gomizunoo..

sen.e: Even after the reinstatement of their family status, Nioko was one of three sisters and her father Ryoukei WAKAE was also adopted which meant they had no male successors so they had to had to adopt children from other families to be third, fourth, fifth, eighth, and ninth successors.

sen.j: 幼少時から学問好きの才媛として公家社会の中では有名人であったが、一方で野暮で理屈っぽい醜女として避けている人も多かったようである。
sen.e: From one perspective, she was studious in her childhood and well known amongst court noble society, while on the other hand there, were many who avoided her because of her yabo (unrefined) demeanor and ugly looks.

sen.j: 早くから岩垣月洲門下生となり漢学に習熟、15、6歳のころには経史百家を完読、数年後には文天祥の著書『指南集』の釈義を書いて周囲を驚かせたと言われる。
sen.e: At the age of 15 and16, she became a disciple of Gesshu IWAGAMI and studied Chinese classics, read through Rekishi Hyakka, and surprise many with her translation summary of "Shinansho" written by Buntensho.

sen.j: その才女ぶりが宮中に聞こえるところとなり、慶応3年8月9日（1867年9月6日）には明治天皇女御となった一条美子（後の昭憲皇太后）の学問師範に抜擢される。
sen.e: The Imperial Palace caught wind of her literary talent and selected her to be a tutor for Haruko ICHIJO who later became a nyongo to the Meiji Emperor.

sen.e: The Imperial Palace caught wind of her literary talent and on September 6, 1867 it selected her to be a tutor for Haruko ICHIJO, who later became Meiji Empress (Empress Dowager Shoken).

sen.j: この時の教育ぶりについて後に昭憲皇太后は「（薫子の）厳しい教育に泣きそうになったこともたびたびであったが、自分の学問は薫子に負うところが大であった」と回想している。
sen.e: Despite Nioko's strict teaching manner that often times almost made her cry, Empress Dowager Shoken largely owes her education to Nioko's teachings.

sen.j: 明治維新後は皇后付き女官として政治的にも絶大な発言力を誇るようになり、建白書を多く書いたことから「建白女」とあだ名されるまでに至るが、儒教に根本を置く彼女の理想は、欧米文化を重視する新政府の方針と対立することが多く、次第に新政府要人から警戒されるようになる。
sen.e: After Meiji Restoration, she wiled an influential voice in politics and wrote many petitions that earned her a nickname "petition lady" although because her ideas based on Confucianism conflicted with the new government's policy that placed importance on the cultures of Europe and America, the prominent people of the new government gradually stayed away from her.
